oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Camp Forrest
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of soldiers and military vehicles pulling out from Camp Forrest.

Camp Peay was named after Tennessee Governor Austin Peay. It was built in Tullahoma, Tennessee as a National Guard Camp in 1926. Camp Peay was renamed Camp Forrest and was one of the U.S. Army's largest training bases during World War II. It was an an active army post between 1941 and 1946 and became a prisoner of war camp on May 12, 1942.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:source: Looking Back at Tennessee Photograph Collection, 1890-1981
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military camps; Military vehicles; Vehicles
